content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my earnings over the course of 75 rounds. Since we are playing against an anonymous opponent, it's impossible to predict their moves with certainty. However, we can make educated guesses based on the payoff structure.

If both of us stick to one choice (either R or B) throughout the game, the best outcome for me is if I pick R and my opponent picks B in each round (since I get 40$ every time while they get 0$). This strategy gives me a total of 75 * 40 = $3000.

However, since it's unlikely that my opponent will stick to one choice for all 75 rounds, there might be instances where I end up picking R when my opponent picks R (resulting in no payoff), or where we both pick B (giving me a payoff of 20$ per round).

To minimize these unfavorable situations, I could mix up my choices to increase the chances of my opponent picking B. For example, I could choose R in the first few rounds, then switch to B for a while, and then switch back to R, etc. This way, I can maximize my earnings while also keeping the possibility of earning 45$ when my opponent picks R (which they might do if they see my pattern and adjust their strategy accordingly).

In this scenario, it's not possible to predict a single optimal choice for all rounds because our opponent's behavior is unknown. Therefore, I would adopt a mixed strategy that involves switching between R and B throughout the game, with the intention of maximizing my overall earnings while minimizing instances where both of us pick the same choice and neither of us earns 45$.

{R} - I will start with R in this round. After that, I plan to switch between R and B to maximize my earnings over the course of the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, since we both picked R in the previous round and we each earned 45$, it suggests that my opponent might also be trying to maximize their earnings by adopting a mixed strategy like mine.

For the next round, I will switch my choice to B to increase the chances of earning more if my opponent sticks with R or switches to B as part of their own mixed strategy.

{B} - I will choose B for the next round. After that, I plan to continue switching between R and B to maximize my overall earnings over the course of the game while keeping a close eye on my opponent's moves to adjust my strategy accordingly.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since we both picked B in the previous round and we each earned 20$, it suggests that my opponent might also be adopting a strategy to maximize their earnings by sticking with B or switching to R as part of their mixed strategy.

For the next round, I will switch my choice back to R to increase the chances of earning more if my opponent sticks with B or switches to R as part of their own mixed strategy.

{R} - I will choose R for the next round. After that, I plan to continue switching between R and B to maximize my overall earnings over the course of the game while keeping a close eye on my opponent's moves to adjust my strategy accordingly.
